>It seems very likely to me that the genome or gene level meta-parameters
>will drift a *lot*, mainly because there isn't much selection pressure
>being applied to them - the pressure is applied whenever a new better
>genome is found, and we can say aha! the set of meta-params on this
>genome/gene must be good. But of course a bad set of meta-params can
>find good genomes to, sometimes.  Assuming a lot of drift you then have
>to consider the possibility that some of these drifting parameters
>aren't working very well, but they are still able to propagate through
>the population (because of low selection pressure) and in fact you might
>end up with a population where only a few of the genomes are actually
>using sensible meta-parameters that have any chance of finding a good
>solution.
>
>No doubt then the ES people have encountered these issues, so some
>reading would be in order before implementing such a system with NEAT.

A-ha!!!

You just inspired me to understand an issue which has been at the back of 
my mind for quite a while but I was never quite able to put into clear 
words.  I think this is quite an important concept.

It's the difference between mortals and immortals.

(e.g. in a system with an "elite" the "elite" are immortal, they live many 
generations)

There's two different types of fitness involved.  Call them "immediate 
fitness" and "iterated fitness".

Immortals must have immediate fitness, they have to successfully compete 
with the rest of the population so their individual fitness must be high 
for whatever day-to-day tasks the population is tested against.  An 
immortal can have defective reproduction machinery without impairing this 
immediate fitness.  As long as it continues to measure up against the rest 
of the population it can hang around forever...  Looked at another way, 
99.9999% of its children may be still-born, but it can afford to wait for 
the one in a million.

Mortals, in contrast have to have iterated fitness.  A mortal with 
defective reproduction machinery is only a transient phenomenon and will 
not be in the next generation.

Thus they evolve under quite different pressures.  In systems without any 
"meta-parameters" in the genes (like plain NEAT) there is little or nothing 
the differential pressure can act upon.  Because there is nothing which 
_can_ change the individuals ability to have children.

ES, on the other hand, has its degree-of-mutation parameters (mutabilities, 
"strategy variables") and these have the effect, as Colin pointed out, of 
changing the (immediate) fitness of not the individual, but its 
children.  This is (in my terminology) changing the iterated fitness.  Thus 
the definition of "iterated fitness" is something like:

IF[1](who) = sum(child in children(who) : Fitness(child) * 
relatedness(child, who))

IF[n](who) = sum(child in children(who) : IF[n-1](child) * 
relatedness(child, who))

[[relatedness of parent and child is 1/2 (with equal probability crossover) 
and parent and grand-child is 1/4...]]

As you see, it varies according to how many generations you look ahead 
(e.g. the current-day IF of any T-Rex is zero...) and is an emergent 
property only visible after the event.

So in ES without an elite ("comma strategy" they call it) we are breeding 
not only for the ability to solve the problem presented, but also for the 
_ability_ to breed solutions to the problem.

Which is what closes the loop and allows the mutability parameters to 
evolve to useful values in parallel with the functional genes.  Whether 
they contribute to the search is a different question...

--

Another point about this is that it is closely tied to mutual fertility 
between two individuals.  e.g. if two individuals are crossed over, 
depending on the compatibility between their genomes, then the offspring 
may be of similar fitness to the parents or else greatly reduced in 
fitness.  This is down to issues akin to the "competing conventions" problem.

Now, if there is no crossover, then there is no drive for the individuals 
to remain mutually fertile.  On the other hand, even if there is crossover, 
an immortal individual may have little drive to be fertile with the bulk of 
the population.  Conversely, if the elite breeds with the non-elite, and if 
the elite father a largish proportion of the children, then the non-elite 
may be held back needing to remain compatible with the elite.

With no elite, the need to remain mutually fertile adds an additional 
factor to the IF of the individuals, e.g. if they are not fertile with most 
of the population, again their immediate fitness is unchanged but that of 
their children reduced.

--

Another (vaguer) point is the difference between merely passing time and 
passing generations.  e.g. if we don't have an elite, then each individual 
lives one generation but during that generation gets only one chance to 
breed (or to be exact, once chance to breed a few times).  The reason this 
may matter is that, in nature, individuals frequently take note of their 
own breeding success when deciding whether to breed more.  e.g.

(1) to some extent a bonded pair will keep having sex _until_ the female 
gets pregnant -- so any (minor) incompatibilities between them (which might 
kill the offspring in the womb) get overridden by persisting until they get 
lucky (without spewing out hundreds of offspring whether they get lucky or 
not).

(2) on a larger scale individuals may not breed at all when they think they 
have enough offspring (in the simplest case because they don't have time 
after caring for the existing ones)

(3) in some species individuals pick a different partner each year, thei 
enables them to exploit (1) within the year but switch to somebody else in 
case they turn out completely infertile

etc etc

         All of which adds up to more than just giving individuals one 
chance to breed in one generation and them being lost from the population 
if they are unlucky.  It is perhaps more like, once we have decided an 
individual is fit enough to breed, making a sustained effort (multiple 
breedings with multiple partners) to produce an offspring, and then, 
following that offspring for at least a short while and if it proves 
unsuccessful, giving the parent further chances.

--

Food for thought...

         Ian
